race.name: UNBOUND Gravel XL
race.tagline: 350 miles of Kansas limestone hell with zero aid stations. The ultimate test of whether you actually like riding bikes or just think you do.

prestige.explanation: The most prestigious ultra-distance gravel race in the world. The XL predates the ultra-gravel movement and set the template everyone else copies. Winning here puts your name in gravel history.

race_quality.explanation: Life Time knows how to run events. GPS tracking via Trackleaders, clear rules, well-communicated course. The self-supported format means they provide less, but what they provide is professional.

experience.explanation: Life-altering suffering that rewires your brain. The combination of distance, self-sufficiency, night riding, and the Flint Hills landscape creates an experience that changes how you think about what's possible.

community.explanation: The XL attracts the true believers - ultra-endurance lifers who've been doing this since before it was cool. Small field sizes (lottery limited) create tight bonds. Emporia itself transforms into gravel mecca.

field_depth.explanation: The best ultra-endurance cyclists in the world show up: Rob Britton, Lachlan Morton, Lael Wilcox, Heather Jackson. Course records keep getting smashed. This is where legends are made.

value.explanation: At ~$250 entry for 350 miles of racing with GPS tracking included, the per-mile value is exceptional. You're getting access to the premier ultra-gravel event with world-class production.

expenses.explanation: Moderate total cost. Entry ~$250, hotels $140-200/night (if you can find one), flights to Kansas City or Wichita, plus you need gear like GPS trackers and serious nutrition. Budget $800-1200 total.

length.explanation: 350+ miles is firmly in ultra-endurance territory. This is 150 miles longer than the already-brutal 200. You're riding through the night, through the next day, and possibly into a second night.

technicality.explanation: Sharp Flint Hills limestone that slices tires, constant line-choice decisions, and you're doing it all while sleep-deprived in the dark. Not singletrack, but the terrain punishes poor decisions severely.

elevation.explanation: 13,500-14,500 feet of climbing across rolling prairie. No massive climbs, but the relentless rollers over 350 miles accumulate into a serious elevation challenge that grinds down your legs.

climate.explanation: Late May Kansas delivers the full weather gauntlet: searing afternoon heat, cold nights, potential thunderstorms, and wind that never quits. You'll experience 24+ hours of weather variability.

altitude.explanation: Emporia sits at roughly 1,200 feet elevation. No altitude-related challenges here - just pure suffering at sea level.

logistics.explanation: Kansas City or Wichita airports are 1.5-2 hours away. Emporia has hotels but they book up fast and prices spike during race week. The small town swells by 50% during the event.

adventure.explanation: Bucket-list event that defines ultra-gravel racing. Riding through the Flint Hills prairie at night, zombie raids on gas stations, watching sunrise after 14+ hours in the saddle. This is what gravel dreams are made of.

black_pill.headline: 36 Hours of Reckoning
black_pill.content: Let's be absolutely clear: the XL is not a longer version of the 200. It's a completely different beast that happens to share a start line. Zero aid stations. Zero crew support. Just you, 350 miles of tire-shredding limestone, and whatever you can carry or buy at gas stations in the middle of nowhere Kansas. You'll ride through the night without sleep, make decisions while hallucinating from exhaustion, and discover exactly what kind of person you are when everything hurts and nobody is coming to save you. Less than half of first-time starters finish. The course record is under 18 hours - most mortals need 25-35. If you're not prepared to suffer alone in the dark, questioning every life choice that led you here, this race will break you. That's the point.
warnings: Completely self-supported - no aid stations, no crew allowed
DNF rate is significant - many don't finish
Requires GPS tracker and navigation skills
Sleep deprivation is real - 17-36 hour effort
Kansas weather is unpredictable and unforgiving

final_verdict.one_liner: The longest gravel race that matters, where the Flint Hills strip away everything but what's left of your soul.
final_verdict.should_you_race: You need to finish a 200-miler first, preferably two. The 36-hour cutoff sounds generous until you're grinding limestone in your 16th hour with 150 miles still ahead. Self-supported means what it says—no crew, no checkpoints, just you and whatever gas stations stay open past midnight in rural Kansas.
final_verdict.alternatives: Gravel Locos 400k gives you similar distance with more technical terrain and aid stations if you want slightly less suffering. Mid South's 100-miler lets you test yourself against the same sharp gravel and weather without the full commitment to psychosis.

course_description.character: Unbound XL is a 350-mile commitment to Kansas limestone gravel that slices tires and punishes poor line choices across the rolling Flint Hills. The course feels like prairie purgatory — constant undulations that never let you settle into a rhythm, with long stretches between gas station salvation points. Sharp, chunky gravel demands constant vigilance while the relentless rollers chip away at your soul one hill at a time.

suffering_zones.label: First Reality Check
suffering_zones.desc: Eskridge arrives right when the course diverges from the 200-mile route, marking your entry into true isolation. The limestone has already announced its intentions on your tires and legs.

suffering_zones.label: The Northern Wasteland
suffering_zones.desc: Alma to Alta Vista represents the most remote section — 75 miles of Kansas nothingness with no resupply options. Your planning mistakes become apparent here, usually around 2 AM.

suffering_zones.label: The Gravel Gauntlet
suffering_zones.desc: Past Council Grove, fatigue meets the course's most technical terrain. Every rock wants to end your race while your body starts the serious negotiations about quitting.

suffering_zones.label: The Final Crucible
suffering_zones.desc: The last 30 miles back to Emporia feel longer than the previous 100. Your bike is destroyed, your body is broken, but the finish line finally becomes real.

course_description.signature_challenge: The 75-mile gap between meaningful resupply points turns nutrition into a high-stakes chess match. Most riders crack not from the hills or the gravel, but from running out of food or water in the Kansas void where gas stations close at 10 PM and your mistakes compound in the darkness.
